deals.highlightsHtml: Rustic cabins on the shores of Metolius River in the Deschutes National Forest; excellent fly-fishing and hiking opportunities
deals.pitchHtml:
Property at a Glance: Lake Creek Lodge

Lake Creek Lodge has remained as a quiet escape on the shores of the Metolius River since the 1920s. Its main appeal hasn’t changed much since then: Follow in the footsteps of its early guests by fly-fishing for rainbow trout and hiking in the surrounding forest. The main lodge and some of the cabins are original to the property, though they’ve since been updated. All cabins feature full kitchens and bathrooms, and many have large decks and gas or wood-burning fireplaces.

  • Ping-pong and foosball tables in the recreation room, along with a pool table and board games.
  • Warm up by the fire in the great room and peruse the lodge’s historical photo album.
  • Grab a cup o’ joe in the Espresso Cafe. Open 7 days a week and serves pastries. Soups are available daily in the dining room.
  • The Bridges Restaurant Open Wednesday – Sunday serving breakfast, lunch and dinner (dinner is served family style by reservation). Pair your meal with the lodge’s wines; $30 dining credit included.
  • Pet-friendly amenities: a blanket, towel, dish, and doggie bags

Camp Sherman, Oregon: Fly-Fishing and Hiking in Central Oregon

The Metolius River burbles through the center of Camp Sherman, a rural community tucked away in the Deschutes National Forest. Its chilly waters are home to some of the best fly-fishing in the state—toss a line in and you might hook rainbow trout, whitefish, or kokanee salmon. You’ll find these same fish on display, along with countless others, at the Wizard Falls Fish Hatchery a few miles up the road.

Venture deep into the Deschutes National Forest for even more outdoor recreation. Hundreds of miles of hiking and biking trails wend through coniferous and sub-alpine forests. Trek a portion of the 100-mile-long Metolius-Windigo Trail—the trail picks up in the nearby town of Sisters—and look out for the mule deer, coyotes, and migratory birds that call the national forest home.

deals.highlightsHtml: Casino resort outside of Las Vegas features slots, video poker, and table games, plus a variety of restaurants, bars, and entertainment
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Fiesta Henderson

Fiesta Henderson is just a 20-minute drive from the Las Vegas Strip, but you don’t have to leave the premises to enjoy a wealth of food, gaming, and entertainment options. The AAA Three Diamond–rated resort features numerous bars, lounges, and restaurants, as well as a 12-theater Regal Cinema showing the latest releases. In addition, there’s an onsite casino open seven days a week and featuring 18 table games and more than 1,600 slot and video poker machines.

  • Free live music is offered Friday and Saturday nights from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. at Coco Lounge; while you’re there, try the signature CocoTini.
  • Eat your way around the world at Festival Buffet, where six all-you-can-eat cooking stations feature Italian, Mongolian, and other international specialties.
  • Good for kids: There’s a large outdoor pool and arcade room onsite.
  • Nearby Attractions: The awe-inspiring Hoover Dam is just 21 miles away. The resort is also just 12 miles from Lake Mead, and includes complimentary oversized parking for boats and recreational vehicles.

Henderson, Nevada: Thriving Suburb Close to the Vegas Strip

A Las Vegas suburb, Henderson is conveniently close to the Strip but also far enough away to be an escape from the bustle. Livability.com named it a top family vacation destination, highlighting the city’s culture scene, which includes area art galleries and outdoor symphony concerts. At the Clark County Museum, visitors can trace southern Nevada’s history via a timeline exhibit. The museum campus also has several historic buildings—including a decades-old barn and a wedding chapel—as well as a walk-in mining trail.

You’ll find the Hoover Dam, one of America’s Seven Modern Civil Engineering Wonders, about 20 miles east of town. Take the guided tour if you want to learn more about the dam’s history and get a look at the inner passageways. Nearby Lake Mead hosts all sorts of watersports, including kayaking and fishing, but the bulk of the lake’s recreation area consists of mountains and valley with trails for hiking.

Henderson’s shopping scene is another draw: the town features one of the most popular malls off the Strip, Galleria at Sunset. The two-level shopping center houses more than 140 shops and five department stores. But Galleria really stands out because of its Southwestern-themed decor, including fountains, palm trees, and a topiary of animals in the food court. Alternatively, The District at Green Valley Ranch offers an outdoor shopping experience with a pedestrian-friendly promenade that’s lined with boutiques and restaurants. There are also ample opportunities to relax here with a lushly landscaped central park and a grassy courtyard where musicians play live on Friday and Saturday nights from May through October.

Must be 18 or older to check in. Credit card required at booking and check-in. Must use promotional value in 1 visit. Not valid with reward points. 11% tax not included.
deals.highlightsHtml: Located just outside Yosemite National Park, the riverside lodge offers scenic views, outdoor hot tubs, and en suite fireplaces
deals.pitchHtml:
Riverside Lodge Minutes from Yosemite National Park

Once it leaves Yosemite National Park, the Merced River picks up speed, developing frothy whitewater rapids by the time it barrels past Yosemite View Lodge. This secluded inn is tucked into the Sierra Nevada mountains along the park’s western border. Guest-room balconies overlook untouched wilderness centered on the rushing river and the towering pines lining it on both sides.

One of these private balconies or terraces is attached to each double-queen river-view room. After admiring the swift-moving waterway, step back inside to warm up by the fireplace or brew a pot of coffee in the kitchenette. Each guest room is also outfitted with a spa tub, where you can make use of the products included with the spa gift basket.

Six outdoor hot tubs burble on the river’s edge, enabling splash wars with passing trout. Use your $10 dining credit to fuel up for outdoor adventures at River Restaurant & Lounge, which serves traditional American breakfast and dinner year-round. The lodge’s convenience store sells groceries for lodgers looking to prepare their own meals and snacks.

El Portal, California: Gateway to Winter Adventure in Yosemite National Park

California State Route 140 follows the snaking Merced River 20 miles into Yosemite National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that welcomes millions of visitors every year. Thanks to low elevations, much of the Yosemite Valley, as well as the Wawona area farther south, remains accessible to drivers, hikers, and snowball poachers throughout the winter.

Crowds are much smaller in the cooler months than during the summer rush, allowing for leisurely exploration of the park as well as an introduction to its cold-weather phenomena. In autumn, the leaves of big-leaf maples, black oaks, and pacific dogwoods turn brilliant shades of yellow and orange, providing a sharp contrast with the park’s many evergreens. During a short span in late February, the Horsetail Fall cascade often glows orange at sunset, flowing down El Capitan like a plume of flaming lava.

deals.highlightsHtml: 9-day tour covers Peru’s top attractions, including Machu Picchu, Lake Titicaca, and the capital city, Lima; includes airfare
deals.pitchHtml:
Delve into Thousands of Years of Peru’s History and Culture

During this 9-day tour from Indus Travels, you’ll see the highlights of modern and ancient Peru. The trip begins and ends in the capital city, Lima, with stops at Machu Picchu and the towns of Cusco and Puno. Guided tours are included at all destinations; other excursions are available for additional fees. The tour includes:

  • Round-trip airfare from New York (JFK), Orlando (MCO), Los Angeles (LAX), Seattle (SEA), Chicago, or Boston (BOS)
  • Domestic airfare
  • Taxes and fuel surcharges
  • 2 nights of standard accommodations at El Tambo Two, Allpa Hotel & Suites, or similar in Lima
  • 4 nights of standard accommodations in Casa Andina Classic Cusco Koricancha or similar in Cusco
  • 2 nights of standard accommodations in Qelqatani Hotel or similar in Puno
  • Daily buffet breakfast
  • Arrival and departure transfers
  • Transportation and sightseeing as per itinerary
  • Excursion to Machu Picchu with Inca Rail train (economy-class coach) with lunch
  • Shuttle-bus tickets and entrance fee to Machu Picchu
  • Bus tickets with Turismo Mer from Cusco to Puno with lunch
  • English-speaking local guides as per the itinerary

Day 1: Flight and Lima

Established by Spanish conquistadors in the 16th century, Lima is Peru’s official capital as well as its cultural center. You can find remnants of the colonial era throughout the city—one of the most striking is the church of St. Francis. Its yellow façade and baroque accents conceal a secret network of underground tunnels inside, where thousands of human bones have been arranged to form elaborate geometric patterns.

Days 2–5: Cusco and Machu Picchu

An included tour on day 2 will introduce you to Cusco, the former Incan capital perched in the Andes Mountains. After taking in the view from San Cristobal Plaza, you can shop for handicrafts and fresh fruit at San Pedro market. The tour continues on to Santo Domingo Church, built on the site of Qorikancha—the Incas’ most important temple. You’ll stroll the ancient Hatun Rumiyoc Street before wrapping up in Cusco’s main square.

  • Forgotten gem: After the Spanish conquered the Inca Empire in the 16th century, Machu Picchu lay hidden for more than 400 years. It was rediscovered in 1911 by American historian and explorer Hiram Bingham. You’ll visit on day 3.
  • Optional half-day tours: Andean horseback riding ($125/person), bike tour ($125/person), standup paddleboarding on Piuray Lake ($225/person), and a visit to Sacsayhuaman archaeological site ($50/person)
  • Optional full-day tours: Sacred Valley ($65/person), ziplining ($275/person), hiking the countryside ($275/person), and rafting on the Urubamba River ($230/person)

Days 6–7: Puno

Set on the shores of Lake Titicaca, the city of Puno is a vital trade center for agriculture. Keep your eyes peeled for alpacas, llamas, and sheep grazing on the hillsides; the animals’ fleece is used in many of the colorful souvenirs and clothing items available in town.

  • Bus tour: A scenic bus ride on day 6 includes stops at an elaborate church known as “the Sistine Chapel of America,” ruins of the temple of Wiracocha, and the mountain pass separating Cusco and Puno.
  • Uros floating islands: The Uru people inhabit about 40 manmade isles built from reeds and set in Lake Titicaca; you’ll travel to two islands on day 7 to learn about their culture.
  • Optional half-day tours: Taquile Island ($75/person) and Sillustani pre-Inca tombs ($25/person)

Days 8–9: Lima and Departure

During an included tour of Lima on day 8, you’ll see intricately tiled sculptures in oceanfront Love Park and visit Huaca Pucllana, an ancient adobe temple. You’ll have the rest of the day to explore on your own, before you fly home on day 9.

  • Eat like a local: Head to Avenida La Mar in the city’s Miraflores district for ceviche, a flavorful blend of raw seafood, citrus juices, and chili peppers.
  • Museo Larco houses more than 45,000 artworks and artifacts from Peru’s pre-Columbian history.
  • Plaza de Armas was the centerpiece of colonial Lima. The plaza is surrounded by a number of notable buildings, including the massive Government Palace and the 16th-century Cathedral of Lima.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. How much would it cost to fly from an airport not listed as part of this deal? This deal is only available from JFK, MCO, LAX, SEA, CHI, and BOS, but you can book your own connecting flights separately.

2. Can we extend our trip before or after the promotional dates for the deal? Yes, you may extend your trip for a supplemental fee at the time of booking.

3. How do I find out if the dates I want to travel are available? The dates available are listed on each option.

4. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available? We suggest calling Indus Travels to redeem your vouchers as soon as possible so that you do not run into this problem.

5. Does my child need a Groupon, and can they stay in my room? Children must be at least 8 years old to travel on this tour. Each traveler (including children) must purchase a Groupon Voucher.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Roast s’mores by the ocean and swim in an indoor saltwater pool at this Oregon hotel
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Tolovana Inn

At nearly 250 feet tall, the jagged Haystack Rock cuts a striking figure against the Pacific Ocean beach just outside Tolovana Inn. The view is especially brilliant at sunset, when the surrounding waters reflect the sky’s warm pink and orange tones. The hotel’s location is enviable not only for its beach access, but also for a nearby shuttle stop that can whisk guests to downtown Cannon Beach.

  • Indoor saltwater pool filtered with natural salt
  • Roast s’mores right on the beach.
  • Get pampered: Select massages and other services are available via Cannon Beach Spa.

Cannon Beach, Oregon: Quaint Coastal Hamlet with Artistic Vibe

The most notable feature of the skyline in Cannon Beach is an enormous rock. That would be Haystack Rock, a 235-foot monolith rising from the sea along the Oregon coast. Tucked between forested hills and the Pacific Ocean, Cannon Beach is a beauty, with dramatic sunsets, wide-open expanses of sand, and gentle waves. Head to nearby Ecola State Park for the full view, complete with migrating gray whales in the distance. You can also take to hiking trails once traversed by members of the Lewis and Clark expedition.

In town, there’s a palpable artistic vibe. Public art installations are scattered throughout, and the streets are lined with local galleries, cedar-shingled boutiques, and wine bars. You can watch a glassblower craft colorful baubles, snag tickets to a live show, or browse the booths at one of the annual art festivals.

deals.announcementTitle: ✈ 7-Day Lisbon and Azores Vacation with Airfare
deals.finePrint: Book by 12/22/15 or promo value expires. Limit 1 per person, may buy additional as gifts. Reservation required, inclusions/airfare/airline subject to availability. Additional fees may apply for some departure dates. $500 fee to cancel; 7-day cancellation required or fee up to Groupon price. Airfare nonrefundable after booking. Must be 18+ to check in. Credit card required at booking and check-in. Baggage fees may apply and vary by carrier. Airfare includes carrier and government taxes & fees. Each passenger is allowed to transport 1 checked baggage with 23 kg (50 lbs) and 1 volume carry-on baggage up to 8 kg (17 lbs) not exceeding 55cm x 40cm x 20cm. $190 fee to travel solo, $135 for extra bed, or $130 half-board (includes dinner or lunch; excludes drinks).
deals.highlightsHtml: Experience the seafood and coastal vistas of Lisbon before jetting off to the lush landscapes and cobblestone streets of São Miguel Island
deals.pitchHtml:
Experience Two Parts of Portugal

You’ll see two sides of Portugal on this getaway: a cosmopolitan city and a laid-back island town. The trip begins in Lisbon, the capital of Portugal and one of the oldest cities in Europe (it predates London, Paris, and Rome by several centuries). After 3 nights in Lisbon, you’ll fly to São Miguel Island, about 1,000 miles off the coast. São Miguel is the largest island of the Azores, a lush archipelago that’s largely unspoiled thanks to its remoteness. This vacation includes:

  • Round-trip airfare from Boston (BOS)
  • 3 nights of accommodations at Hotel Açores Lisboa in Lisbon
  • 3 nights of accommodations at São Miguel Park Hotel on São Miguel Island
  • Flight from Lisbon to Azores islands
  • Daily breakfast
  • Each passenger is allowed to transport 1 checked baggage with 23 kg (50 lbs) and 1 volume carry-on baggage up to 8 kg (17 lbs) not exceeding 55cm x 40cm x 20cm.
  • Click here for flight information

Lisbon

Your home base in the Portuguese capital is the Hotel Açores Lisboa. Located about a 20-minute walk northwest of downtown, this four-star hotel offers modern accommodations close to the heart of the city. The hotel is within walking distance of the Praça de Espanha metro and bus stations. Chic guest rooms are equipped with cable TV and WiFi. There’s an onsite restaurant and bar serving regional dishes. Below are some of our suggestions for how to spend your time in Lisbon.

  • Parque das Nações: This waterfront park contains a promenade, a multilevel shopping mall, and one of the world’s largest aquariums.
  • Torre de Belém is a 16th-century stone tower at the entrance to Lisbon’s harbor. Climb to the top for sweeping views.
  • Hidden gem: The Dr. Anastácio Gonçalves museum is considered one of the most beautiful Art Nouveau buildings in the country. Inside you’ll find 19th-century Portuguese paintings, Chinese porcelain, and Dutch furniture.
  • Tram Line 28: This antique yellow tramcar winds through the Arab Quarter, the downtown district of Baixa, and the nightlife hubs of Chiado and Bairro Alto.

São Miguel Island

Next, you’ll fly from Lisbon to São Miguel Island, where you’ll spend 3 nights at the tucked-away São Miguel Park Hotel. When you’re not exploring the island, you can relax in the hot tub or kick back by an outdoor pool or sunlit indoor pool surrounded by walls of windows. The onsite restaurant specializes in regional cuisine based on local fruits, vegetables, and fresh grilled seafood. Here are a few things to check out while you’re here:

  • Hot springs: São Miguel is a volcanic island, so you’ll have no trouble finding natural pools heated by geothermal activity.
  • São Sebastião Catholic Church: a 16th-century masterpiece with accents of rare brazilian wood and actual gold thread on the inside
  • The Gorreana Tea Estate: Operated since 1883, this is arguably the oldest tea plantation in all of Europe. You can take a tour or sample fresh green tea in the tearoom.
  • António Borges Botanical Gardens is a good spot to see rare local plants, including sinuous indian rubber trees.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. How much would it cost to fly from an airport not listed as part of this deal? A Groupon must be purchased from the available options. To add on a different airport to connect with the cities listed prices will vary with availability.

2. Can we extend our trip before or after the promotional dates for the deal? The offer is for the selected periods only. SATA cannot guarantee air availability or hotel accommodation outside of these periods.

3. How do I find out if the dates I want to travel are available? Please send an email to azores.express@sata.pt or call Azores Express at 800-762-9995.

4. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available? Your Groupon will be refunded.

5. Does my child need a Groupon, and can they stay in my room? Yes, each person needs a Groupon. Rooms can accommodate up to 3 people.

6. Is the price advertised available on every date? Airfare subject to availability. Additional fees may apply for some departure dates. Contact SATA for details.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: All-inclusive resort with private beachfront and abundant dining options; getaway includes round-trip airfare
deals.pitchHtml:
Vacation in Mexico’s Riviera Maya

This all-inclusive vacation sends you to the Caribbean coast of Mexico for 3 to 7 nights of all-inclusive vacation extravagance. Your home base will be the Grand Palladium Riviera Resort & Spa, which spans five resorts with 9 swimming pools, 14 restaurants, and 25 bars among them. This vacation includes:

  • Round-trip airfare from Atlanta (ATL), Nashville (BNA), Buffalo (BUF), Charlotte (CLT), Columbus (CMH), Cincinnati (CVG), Newark (EWR), Indianapolis (IND), New York (JFK), Memphis (MEM), New Orleans (MSY), or Pittsburgh (PIT)
  • 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 nights of all-inclusive junior suite accommodations at Grand Palladium Riviera Resort & Spa
  • All meals and snacks
  • Unlimited domestic alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages
  • El Ranchito Mini Club for kids 4–12
  • Nonmotorized watersports
  • Daily activities
  • Nightly entertainment
  • All gratuities

Resort at a Glance: Grand Palladium Riviera Resort & Spa

This full-service, all-suite resort lies in a calmer section of the Grand Palladium complex, bordering a 900-yard beach and an oceanfront saltwater pool that’s a particularly nice spot to lounge with a cocktail.

  • Premium drinks are on the menu at Hemingway Bar, along with board games and books.
  • Local and international flavors: Choose from a variety of cuisines—including Mediterranean, Italian, and Japanese—at numerous buffet and à la carte restaurants.
  • Watersports: snorkeling, kayaking, catamaran rides, windsurfing, and pedal boating
  • Daily activities include pontoon boat rides around the complex, salsa and merengue classes, and live music in the lobby.
  • Dance the night away in the adults-only disco, which stays open until 2 a.m.

Mexico’s Riviera Maya: Rich with History and Tropical Calm

Just south of Cancún, the Riviera Maya is a nearly 80-mile stretch of Caribbean coastline fronted by towns rich in Mexican culture. For some of the area’s best beaches, clubs, and snorkeling reefs, head to the rapidly growing city of Playa del Carmen. Farther south, Tulum sits on a perch of rocky bluffs and is better known for ancient ruins, including temples and a cliff-side castle. The inhabitants of Tulum—which means “walled” in the aboriginal language—first erected the city’s outer fortress to protect themselves from belligerent invaders. Today, the wall guards the archaeological zone, beginning with an entryway of two corbel arches and a limestone house built over an underwater cave.

Swimming in the secret caves isn’t allowed, but a scenic drive south of Playa del Carmen brings you to the Yucatán Peninsula’s legendary limestone cenotes, freshwater sinkholes created by an underground river system. At the Cenote Cristalino, you can jump from terraced outcroppings into an exposed pool or go snorkeling in underwater caves. You can also watch locals expertly flip, dive, and synchronously cannonball into the clear water at this popular weekend hangout.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. From what airport does the deal depart? How much does it cost to fly from a city that isn’t included in the deal options? Deal options with 3-letter airport codes depart from that specific airport. Deal options with full city names depart from an airport that is assigned at time of redemption with the tour operator. Departures from airports that are not included in the deal options may be available (and may cost more). Call Vacation Express at 1-800-470-3711 for pricing from any airport that isn’t listed on the Groupon Getaways deal page.

2. Can we extend our trip before or after the promotional dates for the deal? Yes, please call us at 1-800-470-3711 to check availability and pricing.

3. How do I find out if the dates I want to travel are available? To check the availability of specific dates within the option you would like to purchase, please call us at 1-800-470-3711.

4. Does my child need a Groupon, and can they stay in my room? No your child does not need their own Groupon voucher. You can purchase their package directly with Vacation Express when making your reservation staying in your room. Prices range from $499–$1,189 and are subject to change.

5. Can the person I’m traveling with fly from a different city? As long as you are sharing a hotel room, the two people traveling together may fly from any city.

6. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available? We will do everything we can to accommodate the dates you wish to travel. In the event that we are unable to do so, the “Groupon Promise” allows you to refund your voucher.

7. Is this deal priced per person? What does “per person, based on double occupancy” mean? This deal is priced per person based on two people sharing a room. If only one person will be traveling, the person has to buy a voucher and pay a solo fee directly to Vacation Express at the time of booking. If you have further questions, please call us at 1-800-470-3711.

8. Is the price advertised available on every date? Airfare subject to availability. Additional fees may apply for some departure dates. Contact Vacation Express for details.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Explore the American West in a camper van; pick up in LA, San Francisco, or Las Vegas
deals.pitchHtml:
7-Day Camper-Van Rental to Explore Western United States

There’s perhaps no greater region for a quintessential American road trip than the West, where national parks, big cities, sprawling deserts, and jagged mountain ranges coexist. With this deal, your trip begins in San Francisco, Los Angeles, or Las Vegas. After picking up your camper van, you can roam the country as you please—1,000 miles of driving is included with this deal (additional miles cost 25 cents per mile).

  • Camper-van model: Each Mavericks Ford E150 is outfitted with one large bed and an additional double bed if you rent the rooftop sleeper for an additional fee. The vans are hand painted by a local artist for a unique, colorful look.
  • Camper-van amenities: bedding, picnic chairs, pots, pans, dishes, cutlery, a heater, and a two-burner propane stove
  • Included accessories package: With this Getaway, you’ll get a portable shower, a GPS device, a bottle of champagne, and a guidebook.
  • Optional add-ons: You can rent a roof sleeper, a tent, bike racks, and snow chains (additional fees apply).
  • 24-hour roadside assistance is available throughout the United States and Canada.

Road Trips

There’s no set itinerary for your rental, but here are some of our suggested highlights:

San Francisco Area

You could spend a week in northern California and not see all the region has to offer, but a few key attractions are must-sees. Yosemite National Park is home to 3 of the world’s 10 tallest waterfalls, the largest piece of exposed granite in the world (known as Half Dome), and a grove of ancient sequoia trees that are among the largest living beings on the planet.

Another popular spot is Lake Tahoe, about 200 miles northeast of San Francisco. The north shore is a popular spot for wine and food festivals in the warmer months, and the south shore is peppered with casinos whose show rooms host everything from live bands to standup comics. South Lake Tahoe is also the starting point for hikes to the base of Lower Eagle Falls. The relatively easy trail reveals breathtaking views of the waterfalls crashing down from above.

Los Angeles Area

Kick off your trip by trekking south down the scenic Interstate 5—practically designed for road trips—as it hugs the Pacific coastline and wends past Laguna Beach and Encinitas, taking you all the way to perpetually sunny San Diego. You could also head inland to Palm Springs to check out the area’s famed midcentury-modern landmarks on a self-guided tour. Stop off for a 2-mile hike through Tahquitz Canyon; the hike’s finale is the namesake waterfall, which you can swim beneath.

About 40 miles northeast is the nearly 800,000-acre Joshua Tree National Park, which encompasses parts of the Colorado and Mojave Deserts. Take a stroll on 1 of the 12 nature trails for a chance to see native animals, such as desert bighorn sheep, snakes, and black-tailed jackrabbits.

Las Vegas Area

Some of the country’s most scenic national parks are within easy driving distance of Sin City. To the southeast, the Grand Canyon, often considered one of the world’s seven natural wonders, is a bucket-list-worthy attraction. Most visitors loop around the South Rim for panoramic vistas of the 1-mile-deep canyon. About 170 miles northeast of Vegas lies Zion National Park and its neighbor Bryce Canyon National Park—both Utah parks with otherworldly landscapes. Zion is known for its narrow slot canyons and sandstone cliffs, and Bryce Canyon has spectacular hoodoos—pillars of red rock formed by erosion.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.announcementTitle: Quaint B&B on San Juan Island in Washington

Must be 21 or older to check in. Credit card required at booking and check-in. Must use promotional value in 1 visit. Not valid with reward points. 10.3% tax not included.
deals.highlightsHtml: 19th-century bed and breakfast set in a small coastal village; enjoy gourmet breakfast, free cookies, and free use of bicycles and kayaks
deals.pitchHtml:
Top Reasons to Stay at Tucker House Inn

  • It’s located in the coastal village of Friday Harbor on San Juan Island, just a block from quaint downtown Friday Harbor and the ferry—a convenient home base for exploring the island.
  • Each morning, enjoy a three-course gourmet breakfast that starts with fresh fruit, housemade granola, and yogurt, followed by a hot entree and a sweet dessert. Fruits and vegetables come from the onsite organic garden and local farmers on the San Juan Islands.
  • The circa-1898 inn has just a handful of guest rooms, each of which features a two-person hot tub and vintage-style furnishings.
  • Your stay includes perks like complimentary housemade cookies each afternoon, use of the inn’s bicycles and kayaks, and free WiFi and parking.
  • This Getaway includes a choice between a bottle of sparkling wine and a $25 dining credit to the nearby Coho Restaurant, where chefs craft Pacific Northwest cuisine with a Mediterranean twist.
  • San Juan Island is a nature lover’s paradise. There are hiking trails throughout Lime Kiln Point State Park, located on the other side of the island. You can sometimes spot orca whales from the shore.

Friday Harbor, Washington: Coastal Village and Cultural Hub on San Juan Island

The San Juan Islands are an archipelago off the coast of northwest Washington in the Salish Sea, the body of water that divides the Washington and from Vancouver Island in Canada. San Juan Island itself is the main hub, home to Friday Harbor—the largest town among the islands. Friday Harbor is also the cultural epicenter, with plenty of art galleries, restaurants, boutiques, and museums.

Frommer’s notes that San Juan Island is the only place where “you can reliably see orca whales from shore.” There’s also the Whale Museum in Friday Harbor, where exhibits include the skeleton of a 3-year-old orca and an interactive display on gray whales.

San Juan Island is also historically significant in a peculiar way: In the mid-1800s, Great Britain and the United States clashed over territorial rights to the islands, due to the land’s precarious position between Canada and the United States. After an American soldier killed a British pig in 1859, the boundary dispute came to a head and both sides geared for battle in what became known as the Pig War. Both countries’ troops were at a standoff until 1871, when the Treaty of Washington was signed, granting full possession of the islands to the Americans. Today, you can visit what remains of the former English and American camps—located on opposite sides of the island. Both are designated as part of the San Juan Island National Historical Park and are popular spots to hike nature trails, pick blackberries, and spot wildlife.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

Not valid with reward points. 10% tax not included. Valid photo ID required.
deals.highlightsHtml: Rooms with private balconies overlook the marina and Columbia River; amenities include WiFi, continental breakfast, and Beach Cruisers
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: The Astoria Riverwalk Inn

Astoria Riverwalk Inn is in the hands of new owners, one of whom helped to establish the award-winning Hotel Elliott in downtown Astoria. The attention to detail shows in the inn’s reinvention with new landscaping and an updated lobby. Guests can also enjoy the Egyptian cotton sheets, an expanded continental breakfast, a business center, 30 Mps Wi-Fi, complimentary DVD rentals, and Beach Cruiser bikes that can be used to explore the riverfront and beyond.

  • Where you’ll stay: a king room with complimentary 100Mps WiFi (capable of delivering 30MPS to any one individual), a private balcony, and a microwave and fridge
  • Enjoy the view: You’ll be able to see the Columbia River and the Astoria Bridge, which leads to Washington, right from your guest room.
  • Dogs are welcome for a small fee (must be 75 lbs. or smaller).
  • Start the day right with a free reinvented continental breakfast that includes fresh fruit, bagels, and Astoria’s own fresh-ground Thundermuck coffee.
  • Get to know Astoria with the museum package, which includes two passes per stay to three local museums.

Astoria, Oregon: Frontier Port with Scenic Hikes and Brewpubs

Tucked away in the northwestern corner of Oregon, the town of Astoria juts into the mouth of the Columbia River, the body of water that separates Oregon and Washington. Known as the “Hip Annex” to Portland and Seattle, Astoria welcomes a number of guests from both areas who come for the emerging brewpub and culinary scene, coffee shops, art, and more. Astoria has a storied past as one of the oldest US settlements west of the Rockies. The town is named after John Jacob Astor, the entrepreneur who founded the Pacific Fur Company and established Fort Astoria in 1811. A few years earlier, in 1805, Lewis and Clark spent a winter camped out at Fort Clatsop; today, a replica fort commemorates the expedition with a visitor’s center and ranger-led programs. Fort Clatsop is also the trailhead for the popular Fort to Sea Trail, a 3-mile hike that wends through forests and across beach dunes en route to the Pacific Ocean.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Family-friendly hotel on Native American reservation features natural hot-springs pool
deals.pitchHtml:
Family-Friendly Resort with Pools Fed by Natural Hot Springs

Natural hot springs dot the land around what is today Kah-Nee-Ta Resort & Spa; the mineral-rich pools were once used by Native American spiritual leaders to create healing remedies. Today, the land is a reservation for the Wasco, Paiute, and Warm Springs tribes, and they invite guests to come stay amid this relaxing atmosphere. The spring water—which reaches 92 degrees even in winter—now feeds into an outdoor pool with two water slides.

Though the mood is very relaxed, there’s no shortage of things to do. Kids can keep busy with outdoor activities such as mini golf and basketball. Parents may favor trips to the hot-springs-centric spa or rounds of golf on the championship course, which stays open year-round. After a busy day, rest up in a modern guest room. Decorated in earth tones to reflect the high-desert environment, each room looks out onto the surrounding valleys and Cascade mountains.

Warm Springs, Oregon: Kayaking and Mountain Hiking on Native American Reservation

Located less than two hours east of Portland is Warm Springs, a reservation for the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs consisting of the Tenino, Wasco, and Paiute Native American tribes. The region is marked by high-desert lands thick with forests and interspersed with alpine lakes and deep canyons. The Warm Springs River cuts through the area, making it a popular destination for kayaking, whitewater rafting, and other outdoor pursuits.

The Cascade Mountains to the west help deflect bad weather, resulting in an abundance of sunny days. The typically pleasant weather makes for a perfect setting for hiking, biking, or horseback riding. From mid-July to mid-October, you can hike through Jefferson Park, which has several scenic trails under the shadow of Mount Jefferson, Oregon’s second-tallest mountain after Mount Hood.

For a more in-depth look at the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs’ culture, visit the Museum at Warm Springs, which Frommer’s calls a “fascinating, not-to-be-missed museum.” Here, you can listen to ceremonial songs, explore traditional Native American dwellings, learn about the rituals of a Wasco wedding, or try your hand at traditional hoop dancing, wherein performers tell a story while spinning up to 30 hoops.

deals.highlightsHtml: 4-star hotel along the California coast offers regional cuisine, natural spa treatments, and roomy suites with private balconies
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Oceano Hotel & Spa Half Moon Bay

Just outside this expansive 4-star hotel, schooners departing from Pillar Point Harbor glide along Half Moon Bay’s peaceful waters. It’s a scenic setting that influenced the hotel’s architecture, which resembles a seaport oasis. Guests here may be tempted to linger on their suites’ private balconies to take in the scenery or the harbor’s famous sunsets, but there are plenty of nearby adventures to take advantage of as well. Bike along the coast, or get your feet wet on a surfing or kayaking excursion.

  • Spacious suites feature private balconies, fireplaces, and 42-inch TVs.
  • Savor fresh seafood and aperitifs at the upscale Oceano Bar and Grill.
  • Sink into a milk-and-honey bath at the onsite spa, which uses organic products in its treatments.
  • Eco-friendly: Conscious of the region’s scenic beauty, the hotel is dedicated to earth-friendly practices, including using natural light in public areas.
  • Shops at Harbor Village: Browse more than two dozen boutiques and restaurants in this greenhouse-style shopping center, located just off the lobby.
  • Downtown San Francisco is about 40 minutes away by car.

Half Moon Bay, California: Historical Town on the Bay Area Peninsula

Charming buildings dating back to the 19th century line Main Street in Half Moon Bay, a seaside town on a peninsula about 30 miles south of San Francisco. Half Moon Bay is largely rural, but it’s close to Silicon Valley, spurring business owners to move upscale restaurants, galleries, and boutiques into those century-old buildings. Local farms and coastal wineries supply eateries with seasonal fare and tasty varietals.

Many of the town’s main attractions can be found along its gorgeous coastline. At Fitzgerald Marine Reserve, small pools fill up along the shore at low tide, revealing hermit crabs and starfish. You can explore the area’s rocky terrain on your own or follow along with a volunteer naturalist, who will gladly point out critters in the sandy coves and monterey cypress trees in the forest. Locals also enjoy spending time at Half Moon Bay State Beach, a 4-mile stretch of oceanfront sand known for its summertime fog in the mornings and evenings.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Experience the capitals of France and England with included flights, 3-night stays in each city, and the freedom to explore at your own pace
deals.pitchHtml:
See World-Famous Landmarks and Museums in Paris and London

This vacation takes you to two of Europe’s most iconic cities—Paris and London—where you’ll have 8 days to take pics of the Eiffel Tower, Buckingham Palace, and other attractions. There’s no set itinerary, so you can explore and take side trips at your own pace. This vacation includes:

  • Roundtrip airfare from New York
  • Airline taxes and fuel surcharges
  • 3 nights of standard accommodations at Best Western Plus Suitcase Paris La Défense in Paris
  • 3 nights of standard accommodations at Thistle City Barbican in London
  • Daily breakfast

Paris

Your vacation starts in Paris, one of the world’s most romantic cities. When you’re not viewing masterpieces at the Louvre, mosey over to the Left Bank, where you can pop into the cafés and bookstores once frequented by Hemingway and Picasso.

  • Arts and culture: Housed in an old train station, the Musée d’Orsay is best known for its unparalleled collection of Impressionist works by Claude Monet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Édouard Manet, and many other 19th-century artists.
  • Iconic architecture: The Eiffel Tower was dismissed by some critics as a “truly tragic street lamp” when it was built. Millions of annual visitors from all over the world would beg to differ. It’s especially beautiful at night, when it twinkles with 20,000 lights.
  • Notre-Dame Cathedral: This 12th-century church towers over the Seine and marks the unofficial center of Paris. Its Gothic spires and gargoyles were immortalized in Victor Hugo’s The Hunchback of Notre Dame.
  • Eat like a local: Stop at any of the myriad sidewalk pastry vendors to try buttery croissants filled with chocolate, handmade crepes, tarts, and more.
  • Optional tours: Tour the Louvre Museum ($67/person), Versailles Apartments ($93/person), or the Paris Seinorama (including a visit to the Eiffel Tower; $74/person). Contact Gate 1 Travel for details.

London

A quick flight takes you to the 2,000-year-old city of London, where you’ll have 3 nights to explore such attractions as Westminster Abbey and Big Ben. Get inside the London Eye ferris wheel’s glass pods to see the city and the River Thames from 443 feet up.

  • Arts and culture: The building that houses the Tate Modern was once a power station. Now it contains 20th-century masterpieces by Andy Warhol, Jackson Pollock, and Pablo Picasso.
  • Iconic architecture: Built after the Great Fire of 1666, the 18th-century St. Paul’s Cathedral is Sir Christopher Wren’s best-known work. Frommer’s calls the domed church the “defining landmark of the city skyline.”
  • Out of the ordinary: Pollock’s Toy Museum houses a quirky collection of wax figurines, early teddy bears, puppets, and mechanical toys from the Victorian age.
  • Eat like a local: Sprinkle salt and vinegar on your fish and chips or nosh on traditional bangers and mash dripping with onion gravy. Other traditional British dishes include hearty beef Wellington and steak-and-kidney pie.
  • Grab a pint at a neighborhood pub—London has approximately 7,000 of them.
  • Optional tours: Add a morning tour of London with a river cruise ($57/person), a trip to the London Eye ($32/person), or a full-day tour of Windsor, Stonehenge, and Bath ($159/person). Contact Gate 1 Travel for details.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. How much would it cost to fly from an airport not listed as part of this deal? Airfare is available from the New York City metro area. The departure airport (JFK, EWR or LGA) will be advised at the time of booked based on availability. The supplemental fee to depart from a city that isn’t included is subject to departure date and availability at the time of booking.

2. Can we extend our trip before or after the promotional dates for the deal? Yes, you may extend your trip for a supplemental fee at the time of booking.

3. How do I find out if the dates I want to travel are available? The dates available are listed on each option. Please call Gate 1 Travel for more information.

4. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available? You can either choose another date or be refunded by Groupon. We suggest calling Gate 1 Travel to redeem your vouchers as soon as possible so that you do not run into this problem.

5. Does my child need a Groupon, and can they stay in my room? Children under 12 do not need a Groupon voucher. Contact Gate 1 Travel directly for child fares (800-682-3333). Different occupancy arrangements can be requested with Gate 1 Travel at the time of reservation. Triple occupancy is not available.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: All-inclusive beachfront resort with a multitude of bars and restaurants, an enormous pool, and a 9-hole golf course
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: The Grand Lifestyle at Grand Oasis Cancun

The Grand Lifestyle at Grand Oasis Cancun occupies a prime spot of beachfront in the heart of one of Latin America’s most popular vacation destinations. The resort is geared toward fun-loving families as well as laid-back visitors looking to be pampered in paradise.

  • Room with a view: Sian Kaan or Pyramid rooms overlook the Caribbean Sea or Nichupte Lagoon (subject to availability). Each unit features a mini bar, Bvlgari bath products, and high-speed Internet.
  • All-inclusive privileges cover three daily meals, unlimited beverages, and a welcome bottle of wine.
  • 29 restaurants and 20 bars: Among the wealth of dining and drinking options: an international buffet, cocktail lounges, sports bars, swim-up bars, and a la carte restaurants serving seafood, sushi, barbecue, Mexican, Mediterranean, and Italian cuisine.
  • See Chichen Itza on an excursion included with this Groupon.
  • Daily entertainment: The resort employs a cast of more than 50 singers, acrobats, and comedians dedicated to keeping guests happy.
  • Enormous pool winding through tropical gardens
  • Tee off on the par 3 9-hole course.
  • Additional discounts: Guests get 15% off spa treatments; 20% off smart car rentals; 10% off wine menu list and premium beverages; 10% off lobster dinner, romantic dinners, red circus, and special events; and other perks.

Cancún: Cool White Sands and Mayan Relics

Located on a barrier island shaped like the number seven, Cancún’s Hotel Zone juts into the Caribbean Sea at the northeast tip of Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula. With the sea on one side and freshwater lagoons on the other, it’s a popular spot for sailing and snorkeling. Although the beaches and barrier reefs are a major draw, the geography is equally enticing further inland, where you can dive into an underground river or take a speedboat through a mangrove jungle.

Cancún pulls in millions of visitors each year, so escaping the crowds and the party atmosphere isn’t always easy, but a visit to Playa Delfines offers a chance for sunbathing in relative seclusion. Resorts have yet to encroach upon this stretch of sand, and it’s especially popular with surfers.

The stone columns of El Rey Ruins, an ancient Mayan site dating back to the second and third centuries BCE, lie within the city’s Hotel Zone. Believed to be a royal burial ground, the archaeological site is also home to wild iguanas that lounge in the sun and read Tom Clancy novels. For a Mayan-themed day trip, take a 1.5-hour drive from Cancún down the coast to Tulum, a pre-Columbian walled city located on a bluff overlooking the sea—one of the Yucatán Peninsula’s most visited Mayan ruins. The Mayan city of Chichén Itzá, chosen as one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in 2007, is only a 2.5-hour drive from Cancún.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. What is the best way to travel to the hotel from the airport? Cancún International Airport (CUN) is 20–30 minutes from the property.

2. Is there an additional occupancy fee, or do I have to purchase another Groupon? The Groupon covers two guests. Adding occupants above standard is $80 per night for each additional guest 3 or older; kids 2 or younger stay free.

3. Will I be approached to attend a timeshare sales presentation? Groupon customers are never obligated to attend a sales presentation. If you are approached and decline a presentation, you will not lose the value of your Groupon or have to pay additional fees.

4. Which activities and amenities are included in the resort credits? Resort credits are not included with the Groupon.

5. Are dinner reservations required for restaurants? Is there a dress code? For information regarding your dining options, please click here.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Mountain lodge near year-round mountain recreation
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Pinnacle Lodge

Pinnacle Lodge sits in the midst of Sun Peaks Resort in the majestic mountains of south-central British Columbia. There are ways to explore the scenic landscape all year round. In the warm seasons, hiking, biking, and golf are popular pastimes. In the winter, you can hit the slopes of British Columbia’s second largest ski resort. Pinnacle Lodge even has ski-in, ski-out access to trails on Mount Morrisey.

  • Skiing season: November 21–April 10
  • Number of trails and glades: 133 across three mountains—Tod, Sundance, and Morrisey
  • Raise your glass: There are more than 120 wineries in the region.
  • In-room amenities: mini refrigerator, balcony, and fireplace
  • Complimentary eats: daily breakfast and afternoon tea (included in $18 per day resort fee)

Sun Peaks, British Columbia: Ski Slopes Steps from Charming Resort Town

No matter where you turn in Sun Peaks, you can see the mountains; they tower majestically, seemingly from all angles. The town has ski-in and ski-out access to nearly 3,700 acres of downhill slopes; Olympic champion and Canadian Senator Nancy Greene often leads tours of the trails. After the snow melts in early summer, the mountains come alive with bikers and hikers. You can catch a ride up the mountain with your bike on Sunburst Chairlift, open daily from late June through Labor Day. From the top, there are 36 mountain-biking trails to choose from, plus a dirt-jumping zone.

The chairlift will also drop off hikers at a more moderate elevation, from which they can access 15 hiking trails. From mid-July to mid-August, the vibrant hillside meadows are covered with wildflowers such as tiger lilies and the mauve-colored fireweed. Keep an eye out for resident wildlife, including black bears, coyotes, moose, cougars, and bald eagles.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: All-inclusive resort with pools, restaurants, bars, and a beach on Jamaica’s northern coast
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Luxury Bahia Principe Runaway Bay

The adults-only Luxury Bahia Principe Runaway Bay resort occupies a beautiful stretch of beachfront on the northern coast of Jamaica. All the guest rooms here are deluxe junior suites with luxurious touches such as hydro-massage tubs and, in most units, views of the sea.

  • All-inclusive perks: Meals, entertainment, 24-hour room service, and nonmotorized watersports are among the bevy of privileges covered in your all-inclusive stay.
  • Relax by the pool or in the spa.
  • Eat up: Dining options include an international buffet and a la carte restaurants serving Italian and Japanese cuisine.
  • Pull up a beach chair and lounge on the sand. There’s a beach bar serving snacks and drinks throughout the day.
  • Number of bars: 8

Runaway Bay, Jamaica: Quiet Resort Town near Natural Wonders

Runaway Bay is tucked into the northern coast of Jamaica, between Montego Bay and Ocho Rios. The secluded town is one of the island’s smallest—Lonely Planet calls it “a one-street village”—and it’s noticeably quieter than its tourist-clogged neighbors. But what it lacks in size Runaway Bay makes up in natural attractions. Some of the best underwater sights in the Caribbean can be explored during scuba-diving tours of the coral reef just offshore. And about 4 miles (7 km) west of town, you can explore the limestone vaults and subterranean lakes of the Green Grotto Caves, which were used as a hideout by Spanish die-hards during Jamaica’s 18th-century colonization by the English.

A scenic 25-minute drive brings you to one of the island’s most popular attractions—Dunn’s River Falls. This natural wonder consists of a series of terraced waterfalls cascading from the mountains to the sea like a gigantic flight of stairs. Thousands of travelers visit the site each year, and it even served as a filming location for the first James Bond movie, Dr. No. Today, tour groups frolic at the bottom of the falls or make the 600-foot climb to the top behind local guides.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. What is the best way to travel to the hotel from the airport? Sangster International Airport (MBJ) is the closest airport. There is a free shuttle.

2. Is there an additional occupancy fee, or do I have to purchase another Groupon? The Groupon covers two guests. Adding occupants above standard is $300 per night for each additional guest 18 or older; kids under 18 are not permitted.

3. Will I be approached to attend a timeshare sales presentation? Groupon customers are never obligated to attend a sales presentation. If you are approached and decline a presentation, you will not lose the value of your Groupon or have to pay additional fees.

4. Which activities and amenities are included in the resort credits? Resort credits are not included with the Groupon.

5. Are dinner reservations required for restaurants? Is there a dress code? For information regarding your dining options, please click here or call (876) 973-7000.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Official Disneyland Good Neighbor Hotel features outdoor pool, free WiFi, and onsite restaurant
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Red Lion Hotels Anaheim Resort

Many nights throughout the year in Anaheim, the sky lights up with fireworks set off by Disneyland—a close neighbor of Red Lion Hotels Anaheim Resort. Guests can snuggle up around the outdoor fire pit to watch the brilliant display. As an official Disneyland Good Neighbor Hotel, the property sells discounted park passes through the front desk. You can walk to the theme park’s main gate—less than one block away—or take advantage of the Anaheim Resort Transit bus system, which stops in front of the hotel.

  • Where you’ll stay: Guest rooms come with refrigerator, microwave, iPod docking station, flat-screen TV, Keurig coffeemaker, and free WiFi
  • Onsite dining: The hotel’s newly remodeled restaurant serves all-American favorites and showcases their smoothies.
  • Head to Long Beach to play volleyball, tour the Queen Mary, or make a sandcastle—it’s just 15 miles away.
  • Make a splash in the heated outdoor pool.

Anaheim, California: Magical Play Land About a Half Hour from Huntington Beach

Less than an hour from Hollywood and Universal Studios, Anaheim is perfectly situated for making the most of a Southern California getaway. But most visitors never make it that far, as Disneyland Park has long dominated the city’s tourism scene. As Walt Disney’s original park, it has a handful of classic attractions that, though upgraded over the years, have been around since the park opened in 1955. You can ride the Mad Tea Party spinning teacups, hop on the King Arthur Carrousel, or sail in the Storybook Land Canal Boats (Walt Disney personally planted the small pine near Geppetto’s home).

Disneyland Park has plenty of modern rides too, including Cars Land, one of the newer additions to Disney California Adventure Park and a life-size re-creation of the town from Disney Pixar’s Cars. The highlight here is the slot-car attraction, which puts you in an automated vehicle that swerves around animatronic characters before engaging another car in a high-speed race.

If you’re in the mood for thrills, ascend the Twilight Zone Tower of Terror before dropping in a heart-pounding free fall, or climb aboard the roller coasters thundering around Paradise Pier with sweeping views of the park. Alternatively, trade fairy dust for white sand in Huntington Beach, where you’ll find 3.5 miles of free-to-the-public beaches filled with surfing, pickup volleyball games, and countless stalls hawking flip-flops and seashell-themed wares.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: All-inclusive resort where you can lounge on a beach, windsurf, drink at a pool’s swim-up bar, and dine at four restaurants
deals.pitchHtml:
All-Inclusive Dominican Republic Vacation with Airfare

Coastal Puerto Plata is renowned for having some of the Caribbean’s longest stretches of unspoiled beaches. Soak up what Lonely Planet calls “world-class sunshine” on this all-inclusive vacation, which includes:

  • Round-trip airfare from New York City, Boston (BOS), Chicago, Buffalo (BUF), Toronto, Raleigh, or Washington, DC
  • All-inclusive accommodations in a superior room at VH Gran Ventana Beach Resort
  • All meals, snacks and beverages including nonpremium-brand liquor, domestic beer, and wine
  • In-room mini bar (replenished daily)
  • Daytime activities, including Spanish lessons and merengue lessons
  • Nonmotorized watersports
  • One hour snorkel equipment, kayak, wind-surfboard, or bike rental
  • One scuba-diving lesson in pool
  • Kids’ club with daily programs and playground for ages 4–12
  • Nightly live music and entertainment
  • Hotel tax, service charges, and gratuities

Optional upgrades: You may upgrade to a premium room for an additional $24 per person per night, or to a Royal room for an additional $32 per person per night. Contact Travel by Jen for details.

Property at a Glance: VH Gran Ventana Beach Resort

As you water-ski, windsurf, or kayak along Gran Ventana’s soft beach, you may not even see the sprawling resort—it’s tucked behind a small but lush jungle. Behind these trees are tennis courts and a sizable pool, where you can enjoy a drink from the swim-up bar. You can also take your included scuba lesson here or find a little peace in the designated quiet wing’s pool.

  • Get your fill at the four onsite restaurants: one buffet, and three à la carte venues serving fresh seafood, Caribbean, and Italian cuisine. You can also enjoy a romantic, candlelit five-course dinner on the beach (additional fees may apply).
  • Relax on your balcony or terrace with a drink from the room’s minibar.
  • Kids’ club: Children aged 4–12 can play volleyball, face off in sand-castle competitions, and take Spanish and tennis lessons.
  • Sweat out toxins in the sauna after a workout in the full-service fitness center. Recharge with a massage and body wrap at the spa (additional fees apply).
  • Tee off at the nearby 18-hole Playa Dorada golf course, which was designed by Robert Trent Jones Sr. (additional fees apply).
  • Notable award: TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence

Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic: Waterfalls, Beaches, and Centuries-Old Historical Sites

Situated on the northern coast of the Dominican Republic, Puerto Plata is best known for its sun-kissed beaches. But the province has several breathtaking geographical features inland as well. Damajagua is a natural water park of sorts—it features 27 waterfalls flowing from limestone rock formations. Tour guides lead groups through the falls, and you can swim and occasionally slide down the natural water slides.

You can get an aerial view of Puerto Plata and the Caribbean Sea on a teleférico, or cable car. One of them climbs 2,565 feet to the apex of Mount Isabel de Torres, which is crowned with blooming botanical gardens and a replica of Rio de Janeiro’s massive Christ the Redeemer statue. It’s also worth it to take a scenic drive to Parque Histórico La Isabela, where you’ll find the remains of a church as well as ruins of a colonial village where Columbus routinely woke his neighbors by blasting the Santa Maria’s foghorn.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. From what airport does the deal depart? How much does it cost to fly from a city that isn’t included in the deal options? Deal options with 3-letter airport codes depart from that specific airport. For options with full city names, a departure airport is assigned by Travel by Jen at the time of booking based on availability. The supplement cost to depart from a city not included is subject to availability. To inquire about availability and cost from your departure city, please call Travel by Jen at 1-800-603-3178.

2. Is this deal priced per person? What does “per person, based on double occupancy” mean? Prices shown are per person and based double occupancy (2 people sharing a hotel room). Each traveler must purchase a Groupon. A single room supplement fee is required to travel solo.

3. Do I need to buy a Groupon for my child? Kids 11 and under pay a reduced hotel rate. Kids 12 and over must purchase a Groupon. Contact Travel by Jen for child pricing at 1-800-603-3178 for child pricing.

4. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available? We suggest calling Travel by Jen to redeem your vouchers as soon as possible to avoid this issue.

5. Is the price advertised available on every date? Airfare is subject to availability. Additional fees may apply for some departure dates. For more details, contact Travel by Jen.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.announcementTitle: Private Casitas on Nicaraguan Island
deals.finePrint: Must book by 1/31/16 or promotional value expires. Travel 1/6/16–5/31/16. Valid only for option purchased. Reservation required, subject to availability. 61-day cancellation notice required for 1/6/16–4/30/16 stays or fee up to the Groupon price; 31-day cancellation notice required for 5/1/16–5/31/16 stays or fee up to the Groupon price applies. Must be 21+ to check in, 12+ to stay. Credit card required at booking and check-in. Must use promotional value in 1 visit. Not valid with reward points. 17% tax not included.
deals.highlightsHtml: Private two-story casitas with lake views on one of the world’s best secret islands, according to Travel + Leisure
deals.pitchHtml:
Property at a Glance: Jicaro Island Ecolodge

Jicaro Island Ecolodge tries to live in harmony with its beautiful setting: a private island in Lake Nicaragua. To that end, the resort—built from trees toppled by a hurricane—stocks only biodegradable soaps and uses an underground electricity system to avoid disturbing local wildlife. Its nine private casitas even blend in with the surrounding foliage. Each two-story unit is raised off the ground, featuring a thatched roof and slatted façades, affecting the appearance of a contemporary treehouse. The resort’s eco-friendly attitude and stunning scenery helped the island earn a spot on Travel + Leisure’s list of the Best Secret Islands on Earth.

  • Named in the top 25 World’s Best Ecolodges by National Geographic.
  • Stylish accommodations: Relax on your private deck’s oversized hammock while enjoying views of the lake, foliage, and Mombacho Volcano. Inside, each unit is decorated with locally made furniture crafted from Rainforest Alliance-certified wood.
  • Watch chefs at work in the open-air kitchen at the onsite restaurant as they prepare grass-fed steak with chimichurri sauce and bananas foster pancakes. Though the menu changes frequently, the restaurant stays dedicated to using locally sourced ingredients.
  • All meals, snacks, and nonalcoholic beverages included with this Groupon.
  • Outdoor adventure: The staff can help schedule numerous tours, including nature hikes, zipline rides, and cultural experiences. To explore on your own, borrow a kayak or standup paddleboard for free and paddle around the islets’ canals.
  • Practice sun salutations during yoga classes on the resort’s dedicated yoga deck, which overlooks Lake Nicaragua and offers views of the Mombacho Volcano.
  • Pamper yourself with a shiatsu or hot-stone massage in the resort’s open-air treatment rooms, which are outfitted with private showers.

Granada Isletas, Nicaragua: Volcanic Islands Off the Shores of an Old Colonial Town

Jicaro Island is one of the Granada Isletas, which are more than 300 small volcanic-rock islands in an archipelago just off the coast of Granada. Visitors arrive on the island by motorboat, and it’s easy to explore the rest of the islets by simply hopping in a kayak. One of the mainland’s highlights is the nearby Mombacho Volcano, a stratovolcano that many climb for fantastic views of Lake Nicaragua. Mombacho has varied ecosystems, including both high-altitude cloud forests and low-altitude dry forests. The volcano is also home to a wide variety of animals, including howler monkeys and iguanas.

The closest city to Jicaro Island is Granada, founded in 1524 by Spanish colonists. Today, the city offers a glimpse of the old Spanish empire at the height of its powers: there are restored cathedrals, colorful squares, and glistening bell towers. Old-fashioned horse carriages still mosey through the city’s cobblestone streets, and vendors showcase hand-carved wood toys and jewelry in the central plaza.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. What is the best way to travel to the hotel from the airport? Granada, Nicaragua is about 26 miles from Augusto C. Sandino International Airport in Managua (MGA). This Groupon includes a round-trip boat transfer from Granada’s Asese Port to Jicaro Island.

2. Is there an additional occupancy fee, or do I have to purchase another Groupon? The Groupon covers two guests. Adding occupants above standard is $160 per night for each additional guest 12 or older; kids 11 or younger are not allowed.

3. Will I be approached to attend a timeshare sales presentation? Groupon customers are never obligated to attend a sales presentation. If you are approached and decline a presentation, you will not lose the value of your Groupon or have to pay additional fees.

4. Which activities and amenities are included in the resort credits? Resort credits are not included with the Groupon.

5. Are dinner reservations required for restaurants? Is there a dress code? Dinner reservations for the onsite restaurants are not required and there is no specific dress code. For more information about your dining options, please click here.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: The beach is right around the corner from this retro-inspired hotel in downtown Santa Barbara
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Inn at East Beach

You can walk to the beach from this 1950s-inspired inn—it’s just a block from the shore. When you’re not out combing the beaches, unwind amid mountain views on the inn’s sun-kissed pool deck or rent a bike to explore the sights in downtown Santa Barbara.

  • Where you’ll stay: Stylish superior rooms blend contemporary and 1950s decor; they all feature flat-screen TVs and free WiFi.
  • Meet Frank: The hotel’s gregarious general manager, Frank Santana, and his wife Linda have a passion for customer service. Be sure to tap into their knowledge of things to see and do in Santa Barbara.
  • Rise and shine: The inn serves a free continental breakfast each morning. Refresh with a complimentary cup of tea throughout the day.
  • Recent award: 2015 TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence

Santa Barbara, California: Charming Beachfront Town Nicknamed “The American Riviera”

The sprawling 400-mile stretch of California coastline between San Francisco and Los Angeles is freckled with scenic, laid-back beach towns. Yet Santa Barbara stands out among the pack, thanks to its prime location: it’s sandwiched between Pacific beaches to the west and the Santa Ynez Mountains to the east. With a population of 90,000, it’s urban, but not overly so—the charming downtown corridor along State Street is a steady parade of mom-and-pop shops, cafes, bars, art galleries, and movie theaters.

A subtle Mediterranean influence graces most buildings: think red-tile roofs, stucco facades, and Moorish-style arches. The climate is breezy and warm year-round, providing an environment for lush tropical foliage to thrive; it’s easy to see why the city bills itself as “The American Riviera.”

To see where it all started, head to the historic Old Mission Santa Barbara, founded in 1786 by a Franciscan friar. Docents offer guided tours of the mission, which houses an art gallery, Native American artifacts, and period furniture. Around the corner, Mission Canyon is a popular trailhead for several hikes in the front range of the Santa Ynez Mountains. Try the 3.5-mile round-trip trek to Inspiration Point for scenic views of the Santa Barbara coastline and the Channel Islands off the coast.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Learn to hand-make pasta with truffles and pair it with wine on this Italy tour, which includes an olive-mill tour; airfare not included
deals.pitchHtml:
7-Day Culinary Tour of Abruzzo

The ancient Abruzzo and Molise districts on Italy’s Adriatic coast are rife with hilltop castles and vineyards. On this 7-day tour, the walled seaside town of Termoli will serve as your home base between hands-on cooking classes and culinary tours around the countryside. The sightseeing tours give you a break from the kitchen and show a side of Italy not seen on most tour itineraries. All your meals are included, and you’ll sample some of the area’s best gourmet cuisine. This tour includes:

  • 6 nights of accommodations in a deluxe room at Residenza Sveva in Termoli
  • Six breakfasts, lunches, and dinners
  • Round-trip airport transfers
  • Cooking and wine-pairing classes
  • Sightseeing tours
  • Fish-market, olive-mill, and cheese-making tours
  • Airfare is not included with this Groupon

See the full itinerary here.

Culinary-Tour Highlights

Cooking Classes

Savor Abruzzo’s storied flavors during four cooking classes. Learn to stuff vegetables and make simple, rustic dishes in the peasant-food class. In another class, you’ll make pasta by hand and infuse it with the earthy flavors of truffles. The last two topics covered are antipasti—a traditional appetizer plate of smoked meats, cheeses, and seafood—and handmade pizzas.

Cheese-Making Tour

In Agnone, you’ll visit a factory where artisans will demonstrate how to make fresh mozzarella cheese. You’ll also get to snack a bit—the tour includes samples.

Vasto Day Trip

The quiet seaside town of Vasto is perched beside the Adriatic Sea. It’s home to a handful of traboccos, or fishing houses jutting out into the water. A little farther inland, you can take a stroll on a quiet beach and shop in the town’s boutiques.

Olive-Mill Tour

The prestigious olive producer that you’ll visit counts Williams-Sonoma and Dean & DeLuca among its customers. Here, you’ll learn how extra-virgin olive oil is made before enjoying lunch amid the olive groves. Afterward, you’ll be treated to an olive-oil tasting.

Where You’ll Stay

Each room at Residenza Sveva features a Mediterranean color palette, marble-painted walls, and a fully stocked mini bar. The hotel offers albergo diffuso accommodations, meaning its individually appointed rooms are located in four buildings in Termoli’s old town. Termoli’s quiet beaches and port are within walking distance of each building, as is the 12th-century, Puglian Romanesque cathedral. A little farther inland, you can tour the 13th-century Castello Svevo.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. How much would it cost to fly from an airport not listed as part of this deal?
Airfare is not included in this offer.

2. Can we extend our trip before or after the promotional dates for the deal?
Contact Epitourean for details.

3. How do I find out if the dates I want to travel are available?
Groupon customers should call 800-390-3292 or email customerservice@epitourean.com to inquire about desired dates. Customers should be a little flexible in choosing their dates. Epitourean will do everything possible to accommodate the requested dates, but we also run this tour virtually every week throughout the year.

4. What happens if I buy the Groupon and my travel dates are not available?
If the dates requested by the customer are not available, they can request flexible dates so that they can use their voucher for a future date (where we honor the discounted price and pre-paid status), or they can request a refund through Groupon, as long as it is within the Groupon refund period.

5. Does my child need a Groupon, and can they stay in my room?
This package is sold on a per person basis regardless of age. Due to the nature of the cooking class focus of these tours, we do not recommend kids under the age of 14. But kids pay the same price as adults in this particular package.

6. Is the price advertised available on every date?
Contact Epitourean for details.

Love to travel? Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for travel tips, inspiration, and photos from around the world.

deals.highlightsHtml: Homey condos near Orlando’s theme parks, with full kitchens and access to a spa, pool, and whirlpool
deals.pitchHtml:
Spacious Condos Close to Orlando Theme Parks

A vacation in the Orlando area is a dream for many families. Nowhere else in the world will you find as many famous amusement parks, from Walt Disney World® Theme Parks to Universal Orlando Resort. Located in Orlando’s neighboring city, Kissimmee, Florida Deluxe Villas provides upscale condos that are spacious enough to house the whole family. From here, you’re within a 20-minute drive of all the parks.

Two- and three-bedroom condos have eat-in kitchens, washers and dryers, and large living rooms. You’ll also find clubhouses outfitted with fitness centers, hot tubs, pools, game rooms, and saunas. Check the Florida Deluxe Villas website for a complete list of available units.

A concierge is on hand to help you plan your time. As an authorized independent retailer for Walt Disney World® Theme Parks, the concierge can sell park tickets directly, as well as discounted admission to other area attractions and dinner shows. After a day at the parks, use your included Restaurant.com gift card to grab dinner at a nearby eatery.

Kissimmee, Florida: Easy Access to World-Famous Theme Parks and Major Orlando Attractions

Located on the banks of Lake Tohopekaliga, Kissimmee sits about 22 miles from downtown Orlando and just 16 miles from the Walt Disney World® Theme Parks. The world’s most-visited entertainment resort spans roughly 30,000 acres, encompassing four theme parks, two water parks, five golf courses, and the Downtown Disney® Area. There’s no shortage of things to do here: begin your day at Magic Kingdom® Park by boarding Space Mountain® Attraction, a rocket-shaped three-seater that climbs to 180 feet before entering a deep black tunnel and racing past stars, satellites, and constellations. After that, ride past the ghastly goofballs inside The Haunted Mansion. For dinner, head over to Epcot® to sample cuisine from Morocco, Mexico, France, Italy, and several other countries at the World Showcase. As one of the most popular family destinations in the world, sunny Orlando is home to other theme parks including Universal Orlando Resort and SeaWorld Orlando.

Those hoping to shake up the typical theme-park-dominated itinerary can head into downtown Orlando’s vibrant arts district. The neighborhood boasts venues such as the CityArts Factory, a multifaceted patchwork of gallery spaces, and SAK Comedy Lab, which holds improv shows five nights a week.

About a 10-minute drive north, you’ll find several cultural institutions surrounding Loch Haven Park, including the Orlando Museum of Art; the collection features pieces by Georgia O’Keeffe, Robert Rauschenberg, Ansel Adams, and Andy Warhol. The park is also home to the Orlando Shakespeare Theater and the Orlando Science Center, where you can take a rover across a simulation of Mars or race model cars down a 70-foot pinewood-derby track.

deals.highlightsHtml: European-style bed and breakfast steps from Pike Place Market
deals.pitchHtml:
Hotel at a Glance: Pensione Nichols B&B

There are no neon lights or roadside billboards advertising the Pensione Nichols B&B; in fact, you might miss the intimate little inn if you weren’t looking for it. It’s tucked away atop a century-old building in downtown Seattle, within easy walking distance of Pike Place Market and surrounded by views of the Puget Sound and the Olympic Mountains. Inside, the inn draws inspiration from Europe, with several antique furnishings that were imported from Sussex, England.

  • A bistro-style breakfast of freshly baked breads, fruit, and coffee helps you start your day.
  • Stylish rooms and suites are trimmed in elegant turn-of-the-century furnishings, but free WiFi keeps you in touch with the modern world.
  • Bring Fido!: Pets can tag along for an additional fee. The innkeeper’s cavalier king charles spaniel, Theo, is likely to welcome you when you arrive.
  • Watch the sunset: The hotel is known for its stunning views of Elliott Bay’s sunsets.

Downtown Seattle: Art, Architecture, and Famous Coffee in Coastal Urban Center

Street performances, flowers, and fresh-caught fish find a common home at Seattle’s Pike Place Market. Founded in 1907, this market is where both sightseers and locals shop for fresh seafood, meat, and produce. Drop into the Fish Market to watch the staff tossing salmon, halibut, cod—a famous tradition. There are plenty of nonperishable goods as well, including jewelry and other crafts. And you might want to take a picture in front of the market’s iconic sign, which now rivals Space Needle as the city’s most-recognizable symbol.

The original Starbucks coffeehouse has operated out of Pike Place since the 1970s. You can stop here for a pick-me-up before taking the half-mile walk to Seattle Central Library. Whether you love books or architecture or both, this futuristic-looking library is worth a visit. The 11-story glass-and-steel structure consists almost entirely of diamond-shaped windows arranged to look like a geometric net. The otherworldly interior is a playground for book lovers. Be sure to check out the library’s “living room” in the morning, when sunlight creates a kaleidoscopic shadow on the floor.

Like the library, the nearby Seattle Art Museum is full of spectacles, starting with its collection of “exploding” white Ford Tauruses suspended from the lobby ceiling. Exhibits range from Renaissance-era European art to Korean and Japanese panels.
